numbered_ace_sentences: 1. The graph shows a higher percentage of young women than young men.
2. A young woman contacts her parents at least once a week.
3. A young man contacts his parents at least once a week.
4. The percentage of young women that contact their parents at least once a week is higher than the percentage of young men that contact their parents at least once a week.
5. Both genders use text messaging the most.
6. Both genders use in-person visits the least.
7. It surprised me that less than 50 percent of young men contact a parent at least once a week.
8. A young man contacts a parent via text messaging.
9. A young man contacts a parent via a call.
10. A young man contacts a parent in person.
11. The question under the title of the graph is: How involved are parents in their children's lives?
12. I wonder if parents are more involved in the lives of their female children than in the lives of their male children.
13. I wonder if young women have stronger relationships with their parents than young men have.
14. I wonder if women are better at communicating than men.
15. I wonder if women are better at staying in touch than men.
16. This relates to our community.
17. Most college students do not live with their parents.
18. Most college students do not see their parents every day.
19. Everyone has different family dynamics.
20. Family dynamics affect how often a person contacts the person's parents.
21. Gender may be a part of this.
22. The graph has a y-axis label.
23. The y-axis label is horizontal.
24. A horizontal y-axis label makes the graph easier to read.
25. The graph uses percentages to compare the data.
26. If the authors used counts then the viewer would have to make more interpretations.
27. If the authors used means then the viewer would have to make more interpretations.
28. If the authors used ratios then the viewer would have to make more interpretations.
29. The viewer would have to make more interpretations to understand the story of the graph.
30. The headline is: What's the Go-To for Parents and Adult Kids to Stay Connected?
